author: pv magazine
title: Today’s old electronics could be tomorrow’s solar panel under circular economy approach – pv magazine Australia
text: The University of Sydney’s Net Zero Institute (NZI) has released a white paper emphasising the need to recycle critical minerals and explore alternatives for essential materials in the transition to net zero emissions. Critical minerals like lithium, copper, and rare earth elements are crucial for renewable energy technologies such as electric vehicles and solar panels. However, the increasing demand for these resources is putting pressure on existing supply chains, making it vital to adopt sustainable practices like recycling and material substitution. “The report points out that products such as EVs, wind turbines, and solar panels have a limited life, and in the absence of recycling, the primary demand will continue to grow, eventually exhausting the resources,” said Professor Deanna D’Alessandro, Director of the Net Zero Institute. “The answer to the challenge of critical materials may be to make them less critical by developing alternate technologies or services that do not require as much of the critical material, or that use a different material entirely.” “As underlined in the report it is important to understand that the goal isn’t just to reach net zero by 2050, but to maintain it every year after that.” Current recycling technologies face challenges due to the complexity and cost of recovering materials from used products, but innovative approaches are being explored. These include advanced bioleaching methods and the development of recycling-friendly product designs to make the recovery of materials more efficient and cost-effective. Finding substitute, alternative technologies for critical materials is also vital, such as sodium-ion batteries and perovskite solar cells which offer promising solutions that reduce dependence on materials like lithium and rare earth elements. For instance, sodium-ion batteries, while having lower energy density, can be derived from seawater and provide a safer, cheaper, and more sustainable alternative to lithium-ion batteries. The NZI advocates for a circular economy approach, where recycling and material substitution are prioritised to ensure a sustainable supply of critical materials. This approach not only helps address environmental concerns but also supports energy security and the economic stability required for a successful transition to a net zero future. The University’s critical minerals and materials research pillar – a team of more than 40 experts across the University, spanning the sciences and engineering disciplines, business, the humanities, social sciences and arts – contributed to the study. The paper is being presented on 3 October at the Net Zero Institute’s biannual NetZero Frontiers 2024 conference which has the theme this year of International Partnerships and Perspectives.

author: Canadian Press
title: B.C. First Nation, Catholic Church announce 'Sacred Covenant' to be signed on Easter
text:
KAMLOOPS, B.C. — Vancouver's Catholic archdiocese is marking Easter with a commitment towards reconciliation with First Nations in B.C., Archbishop J. Michael Miller says.
The church and the chief of the Tk'emlúps te Secwépemc announced Thursday that a "Sacred Covenant" agreement has been reached between the church and the First Nation in Kamloops, B.C.
The covenant comes three years after the First Nation in Kamloops, B.C., announced the discovery of what it believed were the remains of more than 200 children at the site of a former residential school.
Miller said the agreement with the Tk'emlúps te Secwépemc will open a "new chapter" in the relationship between the church and First Nations in B.C.
"Unquestionably, the church was wrong in implementing a government colonialist policy which resulted in devastation for many children, families and communities. We recognize as Catholics, as the Catholic Church, our part in the resulting tragedies," Miller said.
The covenant is set to be signed on Easter Sunday, "a special time of hope and renewal," Miller said.
"Easter Sunday is the ideal time to help start a new chapter in First Nation and Catholic relations in our province," he said. "Our hope and our prayer is that by taking this next step, we will build on our relationship, a relationship already established but still young, and be an example to Canadian society of respecting the identity and the experience of Indigenous Peoples."
Chief Rosanne Casimir of Tk'emlúps te Secwépemc said the covenant will see the church share records and information as the nation continues to investigate the site of a former Kamloops Indian Residential School where hundreds of children went missing.
Casimir said the agreement is crucial to learning the truth about what happened to the missing children, and access to the church's historical records will help "bring justice to the children who never made it home."
"We seek to memorialize the missing children. We also seek meaningful ways to support survivors and intergenerational survivors on their healing journey so that they and their future generations may thrive," she said.
The nation announced in May 2021 that a search around the former school site using ground-penetrating radar found 200 potential unmarked burial sites.
Since then, First Nations across the country have conducted searches and made similar discoveries.
The Truth and Reconciliation Commission identified at least 6,000 deaths at residential schools during their time in operation in Canada between the late 1800s and 1996.
In many of the deaths, schools didn’t record the children's names, genders or cause of death.
The children in the schools were separated from their families and forbidden to speak their own language. They were undernourished and often experienced physical and sexual abuse.
The agreement includes commitments from the church on how to properly memorialize residential school survivors, information sharing about missing children and offering "healing services" to family members of those who attended the school.
Casimir said the possible excavation of the Kamloops school site has not begun as it's a "very sensitive step moving forward," that involves work with other nations, survivors and their families.
This report by The Canadian Press was first published March 28, 2024.
The Canadian Press

author: AFP
title: Australia cricketer Usman Khawaja denied permission to have peace symbol on bat - News | Khaleej Times
text:
Australia's Usman Khawaja has been denied permission to place a peace symbol on his bat and shoes for the Boxing Day Test against Pakistan, reports said Sunday.
A sticker showing a black dove and the words 01:UDHR — a reference to Article One of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights — was on his bat and shoes during training in Melbourne on Sunday.
The star batter had multiple meetings with Cricket Australia over recent days to find a message that would be appropriate for the second Test this week, local media said.
Stay up to date with the latest news. Follow KT on WhatsApp Channels.
But his latest humanitarian gesture has been turned down by the International Cricket Council, The Australian and Melbourne Age newspapers reported.
The ICC were not immediately available for comment.
Khawaja, a Muslim, was stopped from wearing shoes emblazoned with the hand-written slogans "Freedom is a human right" and "All lives are equal" during the first Test in Perth.
The 36-year-old had wanted to show his support for the people of Gaza.
But he was told they flouted ICC rules on messages that relate to politics, religion or race.
He wore a black armband during the match and was reprimanded by the ICC, but insisted afterwards it was for a "personal bereavement" and vowed to contest the ruling.
Khawaja spoke on Friday about how the Israel-Hamas conflict had affected him, saying he despaired at seeing how many children had been killed.
"When I'm looking at my Instagram and seeing innocent kids, videos of them dying, passing away, that's what hit me the hardest," he said.
"I don't have any agendas other than trying to shine a light on what I feel really passionately, really strongly about."

author: VNExplorer
title: Samsung escucha a sus usuarios y extenderá el soporte de todos estos teléfonos
text: La desconocida función de tu móvil Samsung con la que puedes bloquear los álbumes de fotos 10 días con el móvil más vendido de Samsung y sigue con los aciertos (y errores) de siempre Uno de los grandes anuncios realizados por Samsung durante el primer evento Unpacked de 2024 fue que sus Galaxy S24 contarían con una garantía de actualizaciones de software de siete años. Sin duda, una gran noticia para los interesados, ya que hasta ese momento solo tenían la certeza de disfrutar de las siguientes versiones de Android con OneUI y parches de seguridad durante cuatro años. De hecho, para ser más precisos, Samsung solo aseguraba actualizaciones del sistema operativo durante tres años y parches de seguridad durante cuatro. Por tanto, los compradores de teléfonos de la serie Galaxy S20 y Note 20 estaban bastante preocupados, ya que sus dispositivos dejarían de recibir estos paquetes de software próximamente. Algo que les obligaría a renovarlos o a seguir usándolos sin las adecuadas herramientas de protección frente a ciberataques. Confirmado: los Galaxy S24 ofrecerán la misma garantía de software que los iPhone R. BadilloApple convenció a muchos usuarios ofreciendo una característica relacionada con la durabilidad operativa de sus iPhone. Samsung la ha copiado con motivo del lanzamiento del Galaxy S24 Por ello, la noticia recientemente dada por SamMobile , portal especializado en la actualidad de la firma tecnológica surcoreana, ha sido muy bien recibida por los propietarios de teléfonos Galaxy S20 y Samsung Note 20. En ella asegura que Samsung no va a “abandonar” estos dispositivos ni a estos usuarios, los cuales seguirán recibiendo parches de seguridad. Un calendario de actualización trimestral Según SamMobile, Samsung ha incluido los teléfonos Galaxy S20 y Note 20 en su boletín de seguridad de abril , lo que implica que van a recibir un nuevo parche durante los próximos días. Algo que no iba a suceder según lo previsto, ya que el soporte de ambos modelos caducó definitivamente el pasado mes de febrero. Eso sí, dichos modelos no recibirán estos parches de seguridad mensualmente como venía siendo habitual, sino de forma trimestral. Al menos, durante todo lo que queda de 2024 y el primer trimestre de 2025. Habrá que esperar para ver qué sucede a partir de esa fecha, ya que Samsung no ha confirmado si extenderá la garantía una vez superado el cronograma actual.News Related - ¿Los gatos pueden reconocerse en el espejo? Si ve a su felino detenido, viéndose en el espejo, puede que solo esté intrigado o a punto de iniciar un juego. Los felinos pueden tener varios comportamientos al verse en el espejo. author: Tom Eastman
title: Local fourth-graders showcase ski history projects | Local News | conwaydailysun.com
text:
CONWAY — Local fourth-grade students shared their “In Martha’s Memory” New England Ski Museum ski history projects at a showcase event held in the library of Mountainside Intermediate School Wednesday afternoon.
“We had 30 to 40 projects, mostly done in small groups by the 110 participating students over the past month,” said NESM Eastern Slope Branch manager Elaine Stockbridge, who was co-coordinator of the annual ski history exercise.

author: archyde
title: Medvedev’s habit: survived in five sets
text: The Russian Daniil Medvedev, third seed, he needed five sets, four hours and 21 minutes of hard fighting to survive the push and inspiration of the Finn Emil Ruusuvuori, physically exhausted in the final stretch, and advance to the third round of the Australian Open, 3-6, 6-7(1), 6-4, 7-6(1) and 6-0. The lights at Rod Laver Arena did not go out until late in the morning in Melbourne. The face to face between the Muscovite and the tennis player from Helsinki, the third individual between the two, did not have a winner until almost four in the morning, local time. It was a dramatic duel that required an epic comeback by the Russian to impose his status as third racket in the world and maintain his expectations in the first major of the course. I did not expect a situation like this Medvedev who had never lost a round with the Finn. Neither in Kazakhstan, in 2022, nor in Rome, on clay, last year. The curious thing is that the Russian already adds three comebacks from 0-2: the previous ones, Australia 2022 vs Canadian Felix Auger Aliassime and Wimbledon 2021, against Marin Cilic. Now, Medvedev meets the same Canadian in the next section of the tournament in which he was a finalist twice (2021 and 2022), surpassed by Novak Djokovic and Rafael Nadal. All the activity of the Australian Open, exclusively on ESPN and STAR+.

author: Anujj Trehaan
title: Unveiling the Great Barrier Reef's marine majesty
text:
Unveiling the Great Barrier Reef's marine majesty
Stretching over 2,300 kilometers, the Great Barrier Reef in Australia is a natural marvel. It's a vibrant ecosystem, home to thousands of marine species.
Visitors explore coral gardens, see exotic fish, and learn about conservation efforts to preserve this World Heritage site.
The reef showcases the beauty and fragility of our planet's marine biodiversity, offering an unparalleled opportunity for discovery.
Dive into adventure: Snorkeling and diving
Snorkeling and diving in the Great Barrier Reef are unparalleled experiences. Beginners effortlessly float above vibrant coral gardens, observing colorful fish. Certified divers go deeper, encountering turtles and reef sharks. Numerous operators offer guided tours, ensuring safety and environmental respect. This immersive activity not only brings participants closer to aquatic life but also emphasizes the importance of ocean conservation efforts.
Sail the seas: Reef Cruises
Embarking on a cruise is a splendid way to experience the vastness of the Great Barrier Reef. Day trips or extended voyages take visitors to remote, less-visited areas, showcasing pristine waters and untouched islands. Onboard experts provide insights into the reef's ecology, enhancing understanding of this delicate ecosystem. Sunset sails offer breathtaking views, creating unforgettable memories without leaving a footprint.
Learn and protect: Conservation tours
Participating in conservation tours provides insight into efforts to protect the Great Barrier Reef against threats such as climate change and pollution.
These tours often include visits to research stations where scientists share their work on coral breeding and rehabilitation projects.
Visitors learn how they can contribute to conservation efforts through simple actions like reducing plastic use or supporting sustainable tourism practices.
Capture memories: Underwater photography
Underwater photography in the Great Barrier Reef allows enthusiasts to capture its ethereal beauty forever. With clear waters providing excellent visibility, photographers can observe marine life in natural habitats closely, capturing everything from tiny seahorses to grand coral walls. Workshops led by professional underwater photographers assist novices in mastering their craft while promoting awareness through visual storytelling and highlighting the importance of conservation.
